etym: From Middle English tempestuous, tempestious, variants of tempestous, from Old French tempesteus, tempestos, tempestuose, from Latin tempestuÅsus, equivalent to tempest +â€ -uous.
en: If you describe a relationship or a situation as tempestuous, you mean that very strong and intense emotions, especially anger, are involved.
example: For years, the couple's tempestuous relationship made the headlines
example_ko: a tempestuous relationship

etym: From French placide, from Latin placidus (â€œpeaceful, calm, placidâ€), from placeÅ (â€œplease, satisfyâ€).
en: A placid person or animal is calm and does not easily become excited, angry, or upset.
example: She was a placid child who rarely cried
example_ko: a placid baby / horse

etym: The annual mercury (Mercurialis annua), one of the varieties of mercurial (noun sense 1)A sample of a mercurial (noun sense 3), in this case a compound with the molecular formula Ag2HgI4An 18th-century jar used for storing mercurials (noun sense 4) in the form of pills[n 1]
en: If you describe someone as mercurial, you mean that they frequently change their mind or mood without warning.
example: his mercurial temperament.
example_ko: Emilyâ€™s mercurial temperament made her difficult to live with.

etym: From Old French ploiant[1], present participle of ploiier (â€œto foldâ€).
en: A pliant person can be easily influenced and controlled by other people.
example: She's proud and stubborn, you know, under that pliant exterior.
example_ko: her pliant body

etym: From Old French frenetike, from Latin phreneticus, from Ancient Greek Ï†ÏÎµÎ½Î·Ï„Î¹ÎºÏŒÏ‚ (phrenÄ“tikÃ³s, â€œdeliriousâ€), from Ï†ÏÎµÎ½á¿–Ï„Î¹Ï‚ (phrenÃ®tis, â€œdeliriumâ€), from Ï†ÏÎ®Î½ (phrá¸—n, â€œmindâ€). Compare frantic.
en: If you describe an activity as frenetic, you mean that it is fast and energetic, but rather uncontrolled.
example: the frenetic pace of life in New York
example_ko: a scene of frenetic activity

etym: From the Latin Ä«nstÄ«gÄtus, past participle of Ä«nstÄ«gÄre (â€œto instigateâ€), from prefix in- (â€œinâ€) + *stigare, akin to stinguere (â€œpush, goadâ€). Akin to German stechen (â€œto prickâ€), English stick.
en: Someone who instigates an event causes it to happen.
example: Jenkinson instigated a refurbishment of the old gallery
example_ko: The government has instigated a programme of economic reform.

etym: From Latin arrogÄtus, perfect passive participle of adrogÅ, arrogÅ (â€œask of, adopt, appropriate, assumeâ€), from ad (â€œtoâ€) + rogÅ (â€œaskâ€).[1]
en: If someone arrogates to themselves something such as a responsibility or privilege, they claim or take it even though they have no right to do so.
example: The assembly arrogated to itself the right to make changes
example_ko: arrogate  a person's rights

etym: From Middle English eschewen, from Anglo-Norman eschiver (Modern French esquiver), (third-person present eschiu), from Frankish *sciuhan (â€œto dread, shun, avoidâ€), from Proto-Germanic *skiuhwijanÄ… (â€œto frightenâ€). Cognate with Old High German sciuhen (â€œto frighten offâ€), German scheuen (â€œeschewâ€) (German scheuchen (â€œshooâ€)), and Spanish esquivar. More at shy.
en: If you eschew something, you deliberately avoid doing it or becoming involved in it.
example: Although he appeared to enjoy a jet-setting life, he eschewed publicity and avoided nightclubs.

etym: From Middle English enteren, borrowed from Old French enterrer, enterer, from Vulgar Latin *interrÄre (â€œto put in earthâ€).
en: When a dead person is interred, they are buried.
example: the spot where his bones were originally interred.
example_ko: interface

etym: From Latin imbuÅ (â€œwet, moistenâ€).
en: If someone or something is imbued with an idea, feeling, or quality, they become filled with it.
example: As you listen, you notice how every single word is imbued with a breathless sense of wonder.
example_ko: Her voice was imbued with an unusual seriousness.

etym: From the Late Latin exorbitÄns, the present active participle of exorbitÅ (â€œI go out of the trackâ€), from ex (â€œoutâ€) + orbita (â€œwheel-trackâ€); see orbit. Compare the French exorbitant.
en: If you describe something such as a price or fee as exorbitant, you are emphasizing that it is much greater than it should be.
example: Exorbitant housing prices have created an acute shortage of affordable housing for the poor.
example_ko: exorbitant costs/fares/fees/prices/rents

etym: From Middle English fathome, fadome, from Old English fÃ¦Ã¾m, fÃ¦Ã¾me (â€œoutstretched or encircling arms, embrace, grasp, protection, interior, bosom, lap, breast, womb, fathom, cubit, power, expanse, surfaceâ€), from Proto-Germanic *faÃ¾maz (â€œembraceâ€), from Proto-Indo-European *pet- (â€œto spread out, extendâ€). Cognate with Low German fadem, faem (â€œa cubit, threadâ€), Dutch vadem, vaam (â€œfathomâ€), German Faden (â€œthread, filament, fathomâ€), Danish favn (â€œembrace, fathomâ€), Norwegian BokmÃ¥l favn (â€œembrace, fathomâ€), Swedish famn (â€œthe arms, bosom, embraceâ€), Icelandic faÃ°mur (â€œembraceâ€), Latin pateÅ, Ancient Greek Ï€ÎµÏ„Î¬Î½Î½Ï…Î¼Î¹ (petÃ¡nnumi), Ancient Greek Ï€Î­Ï„Î±Î»Î¿Ï‚ (pÃ©talos) [whence English petal].
en: A fathom is a measurement of 1.8 metres or 6 feet, used when referring to the depth of water.
example: We sailed into the bay and dropped anchor in five fathoms of water.
example_ko: [VN] It is hard to fathom the pain felt at the death of a child.

en: If something is floundering, it has many problems and may soon fail completely.
example: What a pity that his career was left to flounder
example_ko: [V] His abrupt change of subject left her floundering helplessly.

etym: From French apogÃ©e, from Latin apogaeum, apogeum, from Ancient Greek á¼€Ï€ÏŒÎ³ÎµÎ¹Î¿Î½ (apÃ³geion, â€œaway from Earthâ€), from á¼€Ï€ÏŒ (apÃ³, â€œawayâ€) + Î³á¿† (gÃª, â€œEarthâ€).
en: The apogee of something such as a culture or a business is its highest or its greatest point.

etym: From Old French epyphanie, from Late Latin epiphania, from Ancient Greek á¼Ï€Î¹Ï†Î¬Î½ÎµÎ¹Î± (epiphÃ¡neia, â€œmanifestation, striking appearanceâ€), from á¼Ï€Î¹Ï†Î±Î¯Î½Ï‰ (epiphaÃ­nÅ, â€œI appear, displayâ€), from á¼Ï€Î¯ (epÃ­, â€œuponâ€) + Ï†Î±Î¯Î½Ï‰ (phaÃ­nÅ, â€œI shine, appearâ€). English Epiphany (of Christ) since the 14th century, generic use since the 17th century.
en: Epiphany is a Christian festival on the 6th of January which celebrates the arrival of the wise men who came to see Jesus Christ soon after he was born.

etym: [1851] Borrowed from French impasse, from French in- + passer.
en: If people are in a difficult position in which it is impossible to make any progress, you can refer to the situation as an impasse.
example: The company says it has reached an impasse in negotiations with the union.
example_ko: to break/end the impasse

etym: From the participle stem of Medieval Latin capitulare (â€œdraw up under headingsâ€), from Latin capitulum (â€œheading, chapter, titleâ€), diminutive of caput (â€œheadâ€).
en: If you capitulate, you stop resisting and do what someone else wants you to do.
example: The club eventually capitulated and now grants equal rights to women
example_ko: They were finally forced to capitulate to the terroristsâ€™ demands.

etym: (verb) From Latin regressus, past participle of regredi (â€œto go backâ€), from re- (â€œbackâ€) + gradi (â€œto goâ€).
en: When people or things regress, they return to an earlier and less advanced stage of development.
example: if your child regresses to babyish behaviour

etym: Borrowed from Middle French impugner, from Latin impugnÅ, from im- + pugnÅ (â€œfightâ€), from pugnus (â€œfistâ€), as in English pugilism (â€œfighting with fists, boxingâ€); from Proto-Indo-European roots.
en: If you impugn something such as someone's motives or integrity, you imply that they are not entirely honest or honourable.
example: The Secretary's letter questions my veracity and impugns my motives

etym: From Middle French acrimonie, from Latin ÄcrimÅnia (â€œsharpness, pungencyâ€).
en: Acrimony is bitter and angry words or quarrels.
example: The council's first meeting ended in acrimony.
example_ko: The dispute was settled without acrimony.

etym: From French cacophonie, from Ancient Greek ÎºÎ±ÎºÎ¿Ï†Ï‰Î½Î¯Î± (kakophÅnÃ­a), from ÎºÎ±ÎºÏŒÏ‚ (kakÃ³s, â€œbadâ€) + Ï†Ï‰Î½Î® (phÅná¸—, â€œsoundâ€).
en: You can describe a loud, unpleasant mixture of sounds as a cacophony.
example: All around was bubbling a cacophony of voices.

etym: From Latin sine (â€œwithoutâ€) + cÅ«rÄ (â€œcareâ€) in beneficium sine cÅ«rÄ (â€œbenefice without careâ€).
en: A sinecure is a job for which you receive payment but which does not involve much work or responsibility.
example: She found him an exalted sinecure as a Fellow of the Library of Congress.

etym: From Middle Low German paltrig (â€œragged, rubbishy, worthlessâ€), from palter, palte (â€œcloth, rag, shredâ€), from Old Saxon *paltro, *palto (â€œcloth, ragâ€), from Proto-Germanic *paltrÃ´, *paltÃ´ (â€œscrap, rag, patchâ€). Cognate with Low German palterig (â€œragged, tornâ€), dialectal German palterig (â€œpaltryâ€). Compare also Low German palte (â€œragâ€), West Frisian palt (â€œragâ€), Saterland Frisian Palte (â€œstrip; band; tapeâ€), dialectal German Palter (â€œragâ€), Danish pjalt (â€œrag, tatterâ€), Swedish palta (â€œragâ€). See also palterly.
en: A paltry amount of money or of something else is one that you consider to be very small.
example: a paltry fine of ï¿¡150
example_ko: This account offers a paltry 1% return on your investment.

etym: From Latin elusus past participle of eludo (â€œto parry a blow, to deceiveâ€)
en: Something or someone that is elusive is difficult to find, describe, remember, or achieve.
example: In London late-night taxis are elusive and far from cheap.
example_ko: Eric, as elusive as ever, was nowhere to be found.

etym: From Latin dÄ“sultÅrius (â€œhasty, casual, superficialâ€), from dÄ“sultÅr (â€œa circus rider who jumped from one galloping horse to anotherâ€), from dÄ“siliÅ (â€œjump downâ€), from dÄ“ (â€œdownâ€) + saliÅ (â€œjump, leapâ€).[1]
en: Something that is desultory is done in an unplanned and disorganized way, and without enthusiasm.
example: The constables made a desultory attempt to keep them away from the barn.
example_ko: I wandered about in a desultory fashion.

etym: parsimony +â€ -ious
en: Someone who is parsimonious is very unwilling to spend money.
example: Due to official parsimony only the one machine was built.

etym: First attested circa 1540, from Middle French, from Latin truculentus (â€œfierce, savageâ€), from trux (â€œfierce, wildâ€).
en: If you say that someone is truculent, you mean that they are bad-tempered and aggressive.
example: 'Your secretary said you'd be wanting a cleaner,' she announced with her usual truculence.

etym: Borrowed from Latin circumnÄvigÄtus, perfect passive participle of circumnÄvigÅ (â€œsail round something, circumnavigateâ€), from circum (â€œabout, aroundâ€) + nÄvigÅ (â€œsail, navigateâ€), from nÄvis (â€œshipâ€) + agÅ (â€œdoâ€). Surface analysis: circum- +â€ navigate.
en: If someone circumnavigates the world or an island, they sail all the way around it.
example: For this year at least, our race to circumnavigate the globe in less than 80 days is over.

etym: Latin circum (â€œaboutâ€) + venire (â€œto comeâ€)
en: If someone circumvents a rule or restriction, they avoid having to obey the rule or restriction, in a clever and perhaps dishonest way.
example: Military planners tried to circumvent the treaty.
example_ko: They found a way of circumventing the law.

etym: From Medieval Latin  postulÄt- (â€œaskedâ€), from the verb postulÄre (â€œto askâ€), from Latin postulÅ (â€œrequestâ€).
en: If you postulate something, you suggest it as the basis for a theory, argument, or calculation, or assume that it is the basis.
example: arguments postulating differing standards for human rights in different cultures
example_ko: [VN] They postulated a 500-year lifespan for a plastic container.

en: An embryonic process, idea, organization, or organism is one at a very early stage in its development.
example: Romania's embryonic democracy.
example_ko: The plan, as yet, only exists in embryonic form.

en: Pestilential is used to refer to things that cause disease or are caused by disease.
example: people who were dependent for their water supply on this pestilential stream.

etym: From Latin annexus.
en: If a country annexes another country or an area of land, it seizes it and takes control of it.
example: Rome annexed the Nabatean kingdom in 106 AD
example_ko: Germany annexed Austria in 1938.

etym: From Old French enemistÃ©, ennemistiÃ©, from Late Latin, Vulgar Latin *inimÄ«citÄs, *inimÄ«citÄtem, from Latin inimÄ«cus (â€œenemyâ€); cognates: French inimitiÃ©, Portuguese inimizade, Spanish enemistad.[1]
en: Enmity is a feeling of hatred towards someone that lasts for a long time.
example: I think there is an historic enmity between them
example_ko: the traditional problem of the enmity between Protestants and Catholics

etym: Late Middle English approbacioun, from Old French approbacion (French approbation), from Latin approbatio, from approbare (â€œto assent to as good, approve, also show to be good, confirmâ€), from ad (â€œtoâ€) + probare (â€œapprove, commendâ€), from probus (â€œgoodâ€).
en: Approbation is approval of something or agreement to it.
example_ko: He said to the merchant that he would purchase the product on approbation.

ko: ì•„ë‚Œì—†ì´ ì¤Œ; (ì•„ë‚Œì—†ì´ ì£¼ì–´ì§„) ì„ ë¬¼, ì¶•ì˜(ç¥å„€).
etym: French largesse, Old French largesce
en: [Noun] (obsolete) The bestowment of a largess or gift.
example: grateful recipients of their largesse.
example_ko: She is not noted for her largesse.

etym: From Middle English abiden, from Old English ÄbÄ«dan (â€œto abide, wait, remain, delay, remain behind; survive; wait for, await; expectâ€), from Proto-Germanic *uzbÄ«danÄ… (â€œto expect, tolerateâ€), equivalent to a- +â€ bide. Cognate with Scots abyde (â€œto abide, remainâ€), Middle High German erbÄ«ten (â€œto await, expectâ€), Gothic ğŒ¿ğƒğŒ±ğŒ´ğŒ¹ğŒ³ğŒ°ğŒ½ (usbeidan, â€œto expect, await, have patienceâ€). The sense of pay for is due to influence from aby.[1]
en: If you can't abide someone or something, you dislike them very much.â†’ see also abidingâ†’ see also law-abiding
example: I can't abide people who can't make up their minds
example_ko: I canâ€™t abide people with no sense of humour.

etym: From Latin repudiÄtus, from repudiÅ (â€œI cast off, rejectâ€), from repudium (â€œdivorceâ€), 1540s.[1]
en: If you repudiate something or someone, you show that you strongly disagree with them and do not want to be connected with them in any way.
example: Leaders urged people to turn out in large numbers to repudiate the violence
example_ko: to repudiate a suggestion

etym: From Anglo-Norman oratour, from Latin orator.
en: An orator is someone who is skilled at making formal speeches, especially ones which affect people's feelings and beliefs.
example: Lenin was the great orator of the Russian Revolution.
example_ko: a fine political orator

etym: From Old French mescreant (1080) "mis-believer", present participle of mescreire "to misbelieve" (modern mÃ©croire).
en: A miscreant is someone who has done something illegal or behaved badly.
example: Local people demanded that the District Magistrate apprehend the miscreants.

etym: 1590s, from inter- +â€ loper (â€œrunner, roverâ€), as in landloper (â€œvagrantâ€) (from lope (â€œto leap, to jumpâ€) (originally dialectal). Originally spelt enterloper and used in specific sense â€œunauthorized trader trespassing on privileges of chartered companiesâ€, later general sense of â€œself-interested intruderâ€ from 1630s.[1]
en: If you describe someone as an interloper, you mean that they have come into a situation or a place where they are not wanted or do not belong.
example: She had no wish to share her father with any outsider and regarded us as interlopers.

etym: Borrowed from Anglo-Norman despeir, from Old French desperer (from Latin despero, desperare), or desesperer, from des- (â€œdis-â€) + esperer (â€œhopeâ€). See also desperate
en: Despair is the feeling that everything is wrong and that nothing will improve.
example: I looked at my wife in despair
example_ko: She uttered a cry of despair.

etym: Borrowed from Old French duresse, from Latin duritia (â€œhardnessâ€), from durus (â€œhardâ€).
en: To do something under duress means to do it because someone forces you to do it or threatens you.
example: He thought her confession had been made under duress.
example_ko: He signed the confession under duress.

etym: Borrowed from Latin Ä“bulliÄ“ns, present participle of Ä“bulliÅ (â€œI boilâ€) + English suffix -ence.
example: His natural ebullience began to return.
example_ko: The Prime Minister was in ebullient mood.

etym: From the Latin inscrutabilis, from in- (â€œnotâ€) + scrutare (â€œto examineâ€), corresponding to in- +â€ scrutable
en: If a person or their expression is inscrutable, it is very hard to know what they are really thinking or what they mean.
example: In public he remained inscrutable.

en: Draconian laws or measures are extremely harsh and severe.
example: draconian measures to lower US healthcare costs.

etym: From French insipide, from Latin Ä«nsipidus (â€œtastelessâ€), from in- (â€œnotâ€) + sapidus (â€œsavoryâ€). In some senses, perhaps influenced by insipient (â€œunwise, foolish, stupidâ€).
en: If you describe food or drink as insipid, you dislike it because it has very little taste.
example: It tasted indescribably bland and insipid, like warmed cardboard.
example_ko: a cup of insipid coffee

etym: Latin pro (â€œbeforeâ€) + locÅ«tus (â€œhaving spokenâ€)
en: a chairman, esp of the lower house of clergy in a convocation of the Anglican Church

etym: From Middle French despote, from Old French despote, from Medieval Latin despota, from Ancient Greek Î´ÎµÏƒÏ€ÏŒÏ„Î·Ï‚ (despÃ³tÄ“s, â€œlord, master, ownerâ€), from the Proto-Indo-European phrase *dÃ©ms pÃ³tis (â€œmaster of the houseâ€).[1] Cognate with Sanskrit à¤¦à¤®à¥à¤ªà¤¤à¤¿ (dÃ¡mpati).
en: A despot is a ruler or other person who has a lot of power and who uses it unfairly or cruelly.
example_ko: an enlightened despot

etym: figure +â€ head
en: If someone is the figurehead of an organization or movement, they are recognized as being its leader, although they have little real power.
example: The President will be little more than a figurehead.

ko: [P] ì¸ì‹í•˜ê³  ìˆëŠ”, ì•Œê³  ìˆëŠ” ((of)); ì¬íŒ ê´€í• ê¶Œì´ ìˆëŠ”
etym: cognizance +â€ -ant, or from Old French conoissant, present participle of conoistre (â€œknowâ€), under the influence of its Latin etymon cognÅscentem, accusative singular present participle of cÅgnÅscÅ (â€œlearn, be acquainted withâ€).
en: If someone is cognizant of something, they are aware of it or understand it.
example: We are cognizant of the problem.

en: When you are conciliatory in your actions or behaviour, you show that you are willing to end a disagreement with someone.
example: The President's speech was hailed as a conciliatory gesture toward business.
example_ko: a conciliatory approach/attitude/gesture/move

ko: ì„±ë¯¸ê°€ ê³ ì•½í•œ, ë¶ˆí‰ì„ ë‹¬ê³  ì‚¬ëŠ”
etym: Perhaps derived from earlier contenkerous, from contentious + rancorous.
en: Someone who is cantankerous is always finding things to argue or complain about.
example: a cantankerous old man.
example_ko: a cantankerous old man

etym: From Middle French contentieux, from Latin contentiÅsus (â€œquarrelsome, perverseâ€), from contentiÅ (â€œcontentionâ€), from contendere, past participle contentus (â€œto contendâ€); see contend.
en: A contentious issue causes a lot of disagreement or arguments.
example: Sanctions are expected to be among the most contentious issues.
example_ko: a contentious issue/topic/subject

etym: Borrowed from Middle French ignoble, from Latin ignÅbilis, from in- (â€œnotâ€) + gnÅbilis, later nÅbilis (â€œnobleâ€).
en: If you describe something as ignoble, you mean that it is bad and something to be ashamed of.
example: ignoble thoughts.
example_ko: ignoble thoughts

en: If your situation is precarious, you are not in complete control of events and might fail in what you are doing at any moment.
example: Our financial situation had become precarious.
example_ko: He earned a precarious living as an artist.

etym: From French facÃ©tieux, from Latin facÄ“tia (â€œjest, wit, humorâ€), from facÄ“tus (â€œwitty, jocose, facetiousâ€).
en: If you say that someone is being facetious, you are criticizing them because they are making humorous remarks or saying things that they do not mean in a situation where they ought to be serious.
example: The woman eyed him coldly. 'Don't be facetious,' she said.
example_ko: a facetious comment/remark

etym: Anglo-Norman aversaire (in Wace's Life of Saint Margaret), from Old French aversier, aversaire (French adversaire), from Latin adversÄrius, from adversus (â€œturned towardâ€).
en: Your adversary is someone you are competing with, or arguing or fighting against.
example: His political adversaries were creating a certain amount of trouble for him.

etym: discretion +â€ -ary (â€œpertaining toâ€). Compare French discrÃ©tionnaire.
en: Discretionary things are not fixed by rules but are decided on by people in authority, who consider each individual case.
example: Magistrates were given wider discretionary powers
example_ko: You may be eligible for a discretionary grant for your university course.

etym: in- +â€ judicious
en: If you describe a person or something that they have done as injudicious, you are critical of them because they have shown very poor judgment.
example: He blamed injudicious comments by bankers for last week's devaluation.
example_ko: an injudicious remark

etym: Borrowed from Latin sacrosanctus.
en: If you describe something as sacrosanct, you consider it to be special and are unwilling to see it criticized or changed.
example: Freedom of the press is sacrosanct.
example_ko: Iâ€™ll work till late in the evening, but my weekends are sacrosanct.

etym: Borrowed from Latin negÄtus, past participle of negÄre (â€œto deny, refuse, declineâ€), reduced from *nec-aiare (or a similar form), from nec (â€œnot, norâ€) + aiere (â€œto sayâ€).
en: If one thing negates another, it causes that other thing to lose the effect or value that it had.
example: These weaknesses negated his otherwise progressive attitude towards the staff.
example_ko: Alcohol negates the effects of the drug.

etym: Borrowed from Latin mercÄ“nÄrius (â€œhired for moneyâ€), from mercÄ“s (â€œreward, wages, priceâ€).
en: A mercenary is a soldier who is paid to fight by a country or group that they do not belong to.
example_ko: foreign mercenaries

etym: From Middle French intermittent, from Latin intermittens (â€œsending betweenâ€), from prefix inter- (â€œamong, onâ€), plus present participle mittens (â€œsendingâ€), from mittere (â€œto sendâ€).
en: Something that is intermittent happens occasionally rather than continuously.
example: After three hours of intermittent rain, the game was abandoned.
example_ko: intermittent bursts of applause

ko: [U] ì²˜ì‹ , ê±°ë™, í–‰ì‹¤, í’ˆí–‰(conduct); íƒœë„, ëª¸ê°€ì§; í‘œì •
etym: From Middle English demenen, demeinen, from Anglo-Norman demener, from Old French demener, from de- + mener (â€œto conduct, leadâ€) + -or, from Latin *minÄre (â€œto driveâ€) and Latin minÄrÄ« (â€œto project or jut forthâ€).
en: Your demeanour is the way you behave, which gives people an impression of your character and feelings.
example: her calm and cheerful demeanour.
example_ko: a kind and gentle demeanor

etym: From Old French eloquent, from Latin eloquens (â€œspeaking, having the faculty of speech, eloquentâ€), present participle of eloqui (â€œto speak outâ€), from e (â€œoutâ€) + loqui (â€œto speakâ€).
en: Speech or writing that is eloquent is well expressed and effective in persuading people.
example: I heard him make a very eloquent speech at that dinner.
example_ko: an eloquent speech/speaker

en: If you describe someone as articulate, you mean that they are able to express their thoughts and ideas easily and well.
example: She is an articulate young woman
example_ko: She struggled to articulate her thoughts.

etym: First at end of 16th century; borrowed from Middle French estimer, from Latin aestimÅ (â€œto value, rate, weigh, estimateâ€); see estimate and aim, an older word, partly a doublet of esteem.
en: Esteem is the admiration and respect that you feel towards another person.
example: He is held in high esteem by colleagues in the construction industry
example_ko: She is held in high esteem by her colleagues.
